channel.title: To order or not to order
channel.description:
[img]http://i52.tinypic.com/8x8y7q.png[/img]
old pic, will be getting i7 2600k and will oc that beast to 4.5ghz, and flash the 6950 to 6970, then oc it sum moar, then run black ops.

item.title: To order or not to order
item.dc:creator: @IlikeArrays IlikeArrays
item.description:
@IlikeArrays wrote:

My original Xbox broke down so I had to pull it all apart and put it altogether again and then I put it on a cardboard box. Cheapest Case I got which was even free! Maybe buying a marker to draw a x on it… but yea…

Read full topic

item.source: To order or not to order

item.title: To order or not to order
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“Greeny, post:19, topic:382721”]I beg to differ, which is kind of the point of my post. Whilst a case in most cases is aesthetics, at the same time it could have been specifically designed for better air flow. Now don’t get me wrong I’m not saying I’m a sucker for the way they advertise these things, but in the same way the chassis of your car could effect the overall reliability and lifespan because of how well protected the engine, or parts are, it surely makes sense for a computer case as well.

While it wont effect performance directly, it will affect performance over time. Now granted, you can just buy a cheap case and modify it, but the average user isn’t going to do that, just like the average user wouldn’t buy any other part and start modifying it.[/quote]

I still haven’t seen a cheap case with airflow so bad it interfered with anything. My case has a fan in the side, 2 in the back, and one in the front. I’ve never had any problems and I have a big, hot 8800GTX in there. My brother has a cheaper case with 1 fan in the front and 2 in the back, running two 9800gtx’s in SLI, no problems there either.

[quote=“Niall, post:20, topic:382721”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=478511.msg3502707#msg3502707 date=1297877139]
I feel like I say the exact same thing on every ‘pc build’ thread here, but here goes again:

  1. The case is far too expensive, you can get one that does the same and looks just as good for $20-$50.
  2. You can get much better graphics performance, for less money, by getting 2 slightly older cards and running them in SLI or Crossfire mode.
    [/quote]

Getting 2 cards for SLI/Crossfire will need a bigger better case, I have an antec 900 and a single long graphics card blocks 2 harddrive slots so getting another would put me down to 1 harddrive unless I do some major hackage and get longer cables, and speaking of cables what a huge mess. Cutting holes in it wont make much of a difference since they aren’t long enough anywa. Oh and 2 cards will run hot, very hot, so good airflow is essential even if you slap a waterblock on everything. There’s also the cost of running another high power component that will make a single more expensive card cheaper in the long run.[/quote]

I can’t use one of my hard drive bays because of my video card. I still have something like 6 drives in my computer, the max it can support, so I don’t see a problem (I did have to remove my dual-floppy drives :(). As to the “overheating” issue, refer to the above.

@Xent, you can get some great looking cases for cheap, mine looks awesome!

Read full topic
item.source: To order or not to order

item.title: To order or not to order
item.dc:creator: @silabsoft RuneAgent
item.description:
@silabsoft wrote:

I use a dell case with the computer i brought to china because dell has some of the best lazy ass hardware removal slots ever. Removing the power supply to trade it out for one here was as simple as holding a lever and sliding it out. I recommend dell cases for anyone bring a computer along for travels that need to swap hardware out quickly.

Read full topic
item.source: To order or not to order

item.title: To order or not to order
item.dc:creator: @xEnt xEnt
item.description:
@xEnt wrote:

Like i’d pick expensive components to shove them in an el-cheapo case with bad design, bad quality, bad airflow and overall cheapness in looks. the case i picked contains some of the best airflow possible, a very well design and it’s got decent looks to it.

about the 2 graphics cards, it’s somewhat untrue. the sandy bridge motherboards are pretty much only crossfire compatible at the moment, which limits me to getting 2 older ATI cards and the older ATI cards have bad crossfire scaling, not to mention using more power and having less features, and having the downside of games that don’t support multiple cards.

Read full topic
item.source: To order or not to order

item.title: To order or not to order
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:4, topic:382721”]I feel like I say the exact same thing on every ‘pc build’ thread here, but here goes again:

  1. The case is far too expensive, you can get one that does the same and looks just as good for $20-$50.
  2. You can get much better graphics performance, for less money, by getting 2 slightly older cards and running them in SLI or Crossfire mode.[/quote]

Getting 2 cards for SLI/Crossfire will need a bigger better case, I have an antec 900 and a single long graphics card blocks 2 harddrive slots so getting another would put me down to 1 harddrive unless I do some major hackage and get longer cables, and speaking of cables what a huge mess. Cutting holes in it wont make much of a difference since they aren’t long enough anywa. Oh and 2 cards will run hot, very hot, so good airflow is essential even if you slap a waterblock on everything. There’s also the cost of running another high power component that will make a single more expensive card cheaper in the long run.

Read full topic
item.source: To order or not to order

item.title: To order or not to order
item.dc:creator: @Greeny Greeny
item.description:
@Greeny wrote:

I beg to differ, which is kind of the point of my post. Whilst a case in most cases is aesthetics, at the same time it could have been specifically designed for better air flow. Now don’t get me wrong I’m not saying I’m a sucker for the way they advertise these things, but in the same way the chassis of your car could effect the overall reliability and lifespan because of how well protected the engine, or parts are, it surely makes sense for a computer case as well.

While it wont effect performance directly, it will affect performance over time. Now granted, you can just buy a cheap case and modify it, but the average user isn’t going to do that, just like the average user wouldn’t buy any other part and start modifying it.

Read full topic
item.source: To order or not to order

item.title: To order or not to order
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

But the case is the only part that doesn’t really affect how the computer runs, how fast it is, how reliable etc etc. It’s a good place to save money while not sacrificing speed, that’s my point.

Read full topic
item.source: To order or not to order

item.title: To order or not to order
item.dc:creator: @Greeny Greeny
item.description:
@Greeny wrote:

Like every component in the computer the case is sold in a whole variety of build qualities and prices. Some are mostly aesthetics but many have “features” such as better air flow, noise reduction etc etc.

The point is there’s not really much point in arguing about cases. Like every part of a computer they’ve been manufactured for the whole spectrum of the market, from budget to billionaire, no doubt.

Read full topic
item.source: To order or not to order

item.title: To order or not to order
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

I paid £35 for my case, a Coolermaster one, its decent, looks nice and is a good cheap-end solution for a case. I hate those £10 cases, they are awful to build in and look at, the quality of the screws and the metal is dire, along with the poor positioning of component bays.

Read full topic

item.title: To order or not to order
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Again, I paid $20 for this case that came with a PSU, I haven’t done anything to it at all, and haven’t had a problem (besides replacing the PSU) for years and years. I’ll probably just always use this case.

(I actually got it free, since it came with a dent in the top of it and newegg refunded me and didn’t want me to ship it back, but that’s beside the point ;))

Read full topic

As to the design and build quality, if it works, and you like how it looks, who cares?[/quote]If you insist on hacking up the Case anyway, why not just build your own? I bought my case because i wanted an effortless solution.

item.title: To order or not to order
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Mopman:

I giggled @ getting a good case for $20

You can, though generally you have to spend $30 unless they are on sale. I paid $20 for my case and it even came with a power supply, which burnt out in about a year, but regardless, I’m using the same case for 5+ years now, it still looks and works great. There really isn’t anything that can go wrong with a case.

@moparisthebest wrote:

I feel like I say the exact same thing on every ‘pc build’ thread here, but here goes again:

  1. The case is far too expensive, you can get one that does the same and looks just as good for $20-$50.
  2. You can get much better graphics performance, for less money, by getting 2 slightly older cards and running them in SLI or Crossfire mode.
